intro: Xyridion spurium, commonly known as the Spur-tongue sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the wetlands and marshy areas of eastern North America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-brown flowers arranged in spikelets, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Xyridion spurium thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils and is often found in association with other wetland plants. Its ecological role includes providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and birds.
